content:
Imagine you are a robot browsing the web, just like humans. Now you need to complete a task. In each iteration, you will receive an Observation that includes a screenshot of a webpage and some texts. This screenshot will feature Numerical Labels placed in the TOP LEFT corner of each Web Element.
Carefully analyze the visual information to identify the Numerical Label corresponding to the Web Element that requires interaction, then follow the guidelines and choose one of the following actions:
1. Click a Web Element.
2. Delete existing content in a textbox and then type content. 
3. Scroll up or down. Multiple scrolls are allowed to browse the webpage. Pay attention!! The default scroll is the whole window. If the scroll widget is located in a certain area of the webpage, then you have to specify a Web Element in that area. I would hover the mouse there and then scroll.
4. Wait. Typically used to wait for unfinished webpage processes, with a duration of 5 seconds.
5. Go back, returning to the previous webpage.
6. Google, directly jump to the Google search page. When you can't find information in some websites, try starting over with Google.
7. Answer. This action should only be chosen when all questions in the task have been solved.

Correspondingly, Action should STRICTLY follow the format:
- Click [Numerical_Label]
- Type [Numerical_Label]; [Content]
- Scroll [Numerical_Label or WINDOW]; [up or down]
- Wait
- GoBack
- Google
- ANSWER; [content]

Key Guidelines You MUST follow:
* Action guidelines *
1) To input text, NO need to click textbox first, directly type content. After typing, the system automatically hits `ENTER` key. Sometimes you should click the search button to apply search filters. Try to use simple language when searching.  
2) You must Distinguish between textbox and search button, don't type content into the button! If no textbox is found, you may need to click the search button first before the textbox is displayed. 
3) Execute only one action per iteration. 
4) STRICTLY Avoid repeating the same action if the webpage remains unchanged. You may have selected the wrong web element or numerical label. Continuous use of the Wait is also NOT allowed.
5) When a complex Task involves multiple questions or steps, select "ANSWER" only at the very end, after addressing all of these questions (steps). Flexibly combine your own abilities with the information in the web page. Double check the formatting requirements in the task when ANSWER. 
* Web Browsing Guidelines *
1) Don't interact with useless web elements like Login, Sign-in, donation that appear in Webpages. Pay attention to Key Web Elements like search textbox and menu.
2) Vsit video websites like YouTube is allowed BUT you can't play videos. Clicking to download PDF is allowed and will be analyzed by the Assistant API.
3) Focus on the numerical labels in the TOP LEFT corner of each rectangle (element). Ensure you don't mix them up with other numbers (e.g. Calendar) on the page.
4) Focus on the date in task, you must look for results that match the date. It may be necessary to find the correct year, month and day at calendar.
5) Pay attention to the filter and sort functions on the page, which, combined with scroll, can help you solve conditions like 'highest', 'cheapest', 'lowest', 'earliest', etc. Try your best to find the answer that best fits the task.

Your reply should strictly follow the format:
Thought: {Your brief thoughts (briefly summarize the info that will help ANSWER)}
Action: {One Action format you choose}
Confidence: {A float between 0 and 1 indicating your confidence level in the action. A higher value means greater confidence.}
Completion: {A float between 0 and 1 indicating how much of the task has been completed until now. Zero means no progress has been made and one means full completion.}

Then the User will provide:
Observation: {A labeled screenshot Given by User}

Now given a task: Search for the one-way flight available from Calgary to New York on May 1st, 2026 with the lowest carbon dioxide emissions.  Please interact with https://www.google.com/travel/flights/ and get the answer.Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: To search for flights from Calgary to New York, I need to change the "Where from?" field from "Toronto" to "Calgary". The input box for this is labeled [13].
Action: Type [13]; Calgary
Confidence: 0.95
Completion: 0.15
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The "Where from?" field has been successfully updated to "Calgary." Next, I need to enter "New York" into the "Where to?" field to specify the destination.
Action: Type [14]; New York
Confidence: 0.98
Completion: 0.25
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The "Where to?" field now says "New York." Now, I need to set the trip type to one-way instead of round trip before choosing the date.
Action: Click [10]
Confidence: 0.95
Completion: 0.30
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The menu to select the trip type is open. To search for a one-way flight, I need to select the "One way" option from the dropdown.
Action: Click [12]
Confidence: 1.0
Completion: 0.35
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The trip type is now set to "One way." The next step is to select the departure date (May 1st, 2026). This is usually done by clicking the date field next to the destination.
Action: Click [12]
Confidence: 0.95
Completion: 0.40
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The "Departure" date field is now visible and available for selection. To move forward in setting the travel date to May 1st, 2026, I should click the "Departure" date field.
Action: Click [16]
Confidence: 0.99
Completion: 0.45
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The calendar is currently showing September and October. I need to move forward to reach May 2026 by clicking the "Next" button multiple times.
Action: Click [73]
Confidence: 0.99
Completion: 0.48
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The calendar is now showing October and November, but I need to reach May 2026. I should keep clicking the "Next" button to move forward several months.
Action: Click [74]
Confidence: 0.99
Completion: 0.48
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The calendar is currently displaying November and December, but May 2026 is still many months ahead. I need to continue clicking the "Next" button to move forward through the months.
Action: Click [74]
Confidence: 0.99
Completion: 0.50
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The calendar is now at December and January 2026. May 2026 is still ahead, so I need to keep advancing the months.
Action: Click [75]
Confidence: 0.99
Completion: 0.52
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The calendar is currently at January and February 2026, but May 2026 is still ahead. I need to continue navigating forward by clicking the "Next" button.
Action: Click [72]
Confidence: 0.99
Completion: 0.54
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The calendar is currently at February and March 2026. May 2026 is still ahead, so I need to continue to the next months by clicking the "Next" button.
Action: Click [72]
Confidence: 0.99
Completion: 0.56
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The calendar is currently at March and April 2026. May 2026 is still not visible, so I need to keep advancing the calendar to reach May.
Action: Click [74]
Confidence: 0.99
Completion: 0.58
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The calendar is now displaying May 2026. I need to select May 1st, 2026, which is labeled [42] ("1$327").
Action: Click [42]
Confidence: 1.0
Completion: 0.70

Thought: May 1st, 2026 has been selected on the calendar. Now I need to confirm this selection by clicking the "Done" button to search for available flights on that date.
Action: Click [78]
Confidence: 1.0
Completion: 0.75

content:
Thought: The emission values for the available flights are visible. The lowest carbon dioxide emissions are 337 kg CO2e, found on both the first (Air Canada/United Airlines, 7:15 AM–1:48 PM, nonstop, YYC–EWR) and second (United/Air Canada, 12:30 PM–9:15 PM, 1 stop, YYC–LGA) listed flights. I am ready to extract and summarize the answer.
Action: ANSWER; The one-way flight available from Calgary to New York on May 1st, 2026 with the lowest carbon dioxide emissions is:

Flight: Air Canada, operated by United
Departure: 7:15 AM from Calgary International Airport (YYC)
Arrival: 1:48 PM at Newark Liberty International Airport (EWR)
Duration: 4 hr 33 min (Nonstop)
CO2 Emissions: 337 kg CO2e
Price: CA$327

A second option with the same lowest emissions (337 kg CO2e) but with 1 stop is available: United, departing at 12:30 PM and arriving at 9:15 PM at LaGuardia (LGA) for CA$338. The nonstop flight above is recommended for the lowest emissions and convenience.
Confidence: 1.0
Completion: 1.0

: ANSWER; The one-way flight available from Calgary to New York on May 1st, 2026 with the lowest carbon dioxide emissions is:

Flight: Air Canada, operated by United
Departure: 7:15 AM from Calgary International Airport (YYC)
Arrival: 1:48 PM at Newark Liberty International Airport (EWR)
Duration: 4 hr 33 min (Nonstop)
CO2 Emissions: 337 kg CO2e
Price: CA$327

A second option with the same lowest emissions (337 kg CO2e) but with 1 stop is available: United, departing at 12:30 PM and arriving at 9:15 PM at LaGuardia (LGA) for CA$338. The nonstop flight above is recommended for the lowest emissions and convenience
